Research

My lab develops optical spectroscopic and imaging methods to quantify physiological, structural and metabolic properties of biological tissues in living organisms ranging from humans through mice. Applications of these tools include detection of cancer, providing early indicators of therapeutic progress on a per-individual basis during conventional anti-cancer treatments, imaging blood flow to detect peripheral artery disease or hemorrhage, and assessing brain activity during cognitive tasks. Much of this research is highly inter-disciplinary and brings the power of optical spectroscopy for biomedical sensing. The fundamental motivation behind this work is to non-invasively observe, model and understand how physics makes biology work.

My research interests span three realms:

1) Instrumentation development for optical sensing

Experimental implementations of optical techniques can be exquisitely complex or quite basic, depending on the desired outcomes or needs. Simple optical spectroscopic systems for routine monitoring of tissue physiology at patient bedside can be assembled with small form-factors for under $5000 using commercially available off-the-shelf light sources and detectors. Innovations in the semi-conductor and optical communication industries might facilitate building devices that would be yet more sensitive while having even more smaller foot-prints, allowing optical biomedical imaging to be performed at several different spatial and/or temporal scales. My goals are to improve the existing platform of optical methods to increase resolution and performance while in parallel, build cost-effective, simple and self-contained optical spectroscopic tools particularly for global health applications in cancer.

Ongoing projects include:

  • Imaging diffuse reflectance using an iPhone
  • Wide-field laser speckle imaging for measuring blood flow
  • Fiber-optic based sensing of blood flow via diffuse correlation spectroscopy
  • Development of a low-cost autocorrelator using a Raspberry-Pi
  • Combined fiber-optic sensor for diffuse reflectance and fluorescence spectroscopy of tissues

2) Applications of optical methods in human or animal studies

In cancer biology, the tumor microenvironment – specifically when cast in terms of its vascular network and oxygenation status - is known to modulate cancer growth as well as its response to administered treatments. As oxygen bound hemoglobin has a distinct intrinsic optical absorption spectrum, optical spectroscopy of tissue can directly sense blood oxygenation and tissue hemoglobin concentration. A couple of factors allow for the routine use of these measurements in clinical and pre-clinical studies to monitor solid tumors in their native environments or states. First, these measurements can be obtained quickly and easily by delivering and collecting light from tissue via thin, flexible fiber-optic probes. Second, they can be done without need for exogenous contrast, and finally they are virtually painless. I intend to continue my study of tumor biology using optical methods to measure longitudinal changes of physiological endpoints to determine whether they can isolate early predictors of treatment outcome.

3) Quantitative theoretical and computational tools for optical imaging and spectroscopy

The effect of light scattering in biological media leads to problems with direct optical imaging and with Beer’s law based approaches for estimation of tissue chromophore or fluorophore concentrations. Theoretical and numerical models of light transport in turbid media are typically implemented as “forward” solutions, meaning that given the optical and structural properties of the tissue, these models can accurately compute the signals at specified detectors. In practice, however, it is necessary to solve the “inverse” problem, i.e. given measured signals at specific source-detector configurations, the tissue optical and structural properties need to be determined. My goals are to advance theoretical and computational light transport methods and models while simultaneously optimize their applications in inverse problems to best quantify tissue optical properties and structure.
